entry.title: Issue While posting Idoc in SAP ECC- SAP BTP-CI
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am facing one issue while posting IDoc in SAP ECC through BTP-CI. However everything is working fine in CI-TEST  but in CI- QA its giving issue

My scenario is SFTP-->BTP CI-->SAP ECC( IDoc)

While posting IDoc in QA SAP ECC its failing due to below error;

Error Details
org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: Response was of unexpected text/html ContentType. Incoming portion of HTML stream: (none)
 
In SAP ECC i checked SICF service is activated however while registering in SRTIDOC its giving error as " Error in Change and Transport system"
As per s-note
2943773 - ESI - SRTIDOC: Error in Change and Transport System we chose second option as move the configuration through transport from lower environment to higher environment however issue still persists. 
 
Can anyone please help here?
In dev its working fine but in QA its failing.
 
Regards
Ankur Chopra

entry.title: Connection Issue Between SAP BTP Trial and S/4HANA On-Premise via Cloud Connector
entry.content:
Hi All,

I’m currently configuring the connectivity between our SAP BTP free trial account and our S/4HANA on-premise system using the Cloud Connector. After completing the setup, I tried to validate the connection between the cloud and on-premise systems, but I encountered an error.

Upon checking the related SAP Note, it seems that the issue might be due to a possible spelling mistake in the host name or a connectivity issue with the internal host.

I have verified that the internal hostname and port are correct, and I also checked in SICF in on-premise system to ensure the correct internal host and port are maintained. However, the connection is still not working. I’m using an HTTPS connection.

Could you please help me resolve this issue?

BR/Kannan.

entry.title: SOAP API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest for creating a product with classification
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We need to create products with related classifications and characteristics via API in S/4 Hana Cloud Public. For with purpose we use standard SOAP API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest ( https://api.sap.com/api/PRODUCTMDMBULKREPLICATEREQUEST/overview ). 

But we have a problem: when we're consuming the web service from ABAP Environment ( from custom class from Eclipse ), we get errors  in SOAP Log Message:

 

Log Messages

 
Consumer:
  • Web service processing error; more details in the web service error log on provider side (UTC timestamp 20251027114623; Transact
  • soap-env : http://schemas.xmlsoap. org/soap/envelope/
  • faultcode : soap-env:Server
  • faultstring : Web service processing error; more details in the web service error log on provider side (UTC timestamp 20251027114623; Transa ... Show More
  • lang : en
     
    Provider:
    SRT: Plain SOAP: Reliable messaging (RM) configured, but consumer sends QoS BE request.
     We are trying to call the SOAP web service within SAP: Source and Target both are S4 HANA public cloud system.

 

Here are our actions step-by-step:

1. Created a Communication User in the Maintain Communication Users app  in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

2. Created a communication system in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition and added as inbound communication user created in step 1

3.  Created a communication arrangement based on the communication scenario SAP_COM_0009. Deactivate all Outbound Services. And then downloaded WSDL file of Product Master - Replicate from Client to SAP S/4HANA Cloud

4. Created in ADT a service consumption model for the targeted web service from the metadata file from step 3.

5. Created in ADT  an outbound service.

6. Created in ADT  a communication scenario and assign the outbound service to it. Chose the Authentication Methods Basic and X.509.

7.  Then in Communication Arrangements app created another communication arrangement based on our custom communication scenario, as well as a new communication system and an outbound communication user from step 1.

8.  Checked connection: we get "The ping of the outbound service was successful".

9. For the implementation of the outbound call, we used the code sample copied earlier from the service consumption model

I would really appreciate any help. Many thanks in advance for your help.

entry.title: EntraID Token Propagation via SAP Approuter for Azure destinations?
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

My question is related to an integration case, where I want to privately integrate data from a SAP backend to an Azure Storage account.

Situation: Write Data from the backend (S/4) via Integration Suite to a private Storage account. I am using SAP private link service (PLS) to be able to reach the private endpoint of the azure storage account, the destination call must be made via an SAP approuter, as there is no direct way of calling the PLS destination directly in SAP Integration Suite.

Problem: Even though the approuter supports token propagation, i could not figure out a way of chaining the propagation, so that I authenticate at the Approuter protected by Cloud IAS (with MS Entra as corp. IdP), translate the token to back to the correct format, that is then presented to the Storage account. The issue lies in the audience claim of the JWT token. For authenticating against the storage account the scope has to match the targeted azure resource (https://storage.azure.com in this case), the claim required by the approuter, however, is the client id of the Cloud IAS application. 

Question(s): Is this integration case even supported by SAP Cloud IAS / MS Entra Token Propagation in combination with using the SAP approuter? My assumption was, since all resources are protected by the same Entra Id tenant, it must be possible to propagate/translate the token to the respective resources?

Another interesting questions would be, if there is a planned feature to support Private Link Service directly via Integration Suite instead of the work-around via the approuter?


Thanks a lot in advance for any response. 

Best Regards 
Matthias

entry.title: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JDBC
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)  
 
JDBC – JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY 
 
Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API : 
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access. 
 
Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging 
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. 
 
Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).  
 
For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section. 
 
Prerequisites: 

  1. SAP DataSphere – Subscribed account (⚠ Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported) 
  1. SAP Integration Suite – Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported) 

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide : 
 

Step 

Action / Notes 

1. Create a Space 

DataSphere → Space Management → New Space → Name it → Create. 

2. Create Table / Analytical Model 

Data Builder → In your Space → New → Table or Analytical Model → define fields & data types → Save & Publish. 
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. * 

3. Prepare / Load Data 

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration. 

4. Note Schema & Object Names 

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use. 
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name * 

5. Decide Where to Create DB User 

If HANA Cloud → use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB → use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin. 
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session* 

6. Create JDBC DB User 

DB admin tool → Security/Users → New User → set username & strong password → Save. 
*Check Active status of User* 

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user 

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign. 

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details 

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com 
Format for CPI JDBC Material: 
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true 

 
SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide : 
 
Create a Package & Artifact 

  • In CPI → Design → Create a new package → Add an integration flow artifact. 
  • ✅ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts. 
     

Go to Monitoring → JDBC Material 

  • In CPI → Monitor → Integrations and APIs → Manage Security → JDBC Material

     

     
  • → Add JDBC Data Source. → Select HANA cloud  

     

     
     
  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true). 

     

     
  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere). 

     

     
  • Save and deploy the JDBC material. 
    •  

    Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

    • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter → select the JDBC data source created.
    • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, I’m using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

     


    Step 1: Timer Start
     In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule → None → On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

     


    Step 2: Content Modifier
    Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
     SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

     



    Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
         → Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
    → JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

     


    Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

     



    References :

    CPI JDBC – XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
     link:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: Guidance for Creating Sales Order from External System to SAP Public Cloud Using CPI
entry.content:
Hi SAP Exports,

I am currently working on creating a sales order from an external system dynamically. While going through various blogs and videos, I was unable to find a complete and proper document that clearly explains how to create the sales order from an external system and access the data through Postman using JSON Web Token (JWT) or OAuth 2.0 authentication.

Could you please guide me on:

  • Which authentication method (JWT or OAuth 2.0) is easier to implement for this scenario?

  • The step-by-step process to create the sales order, starting from the external system up to testing in Postman.

  • How to handle the payload and mapping of fields.

I have already created the communication arrangements and am using the standard API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub (A2X). However, I am currently stuck at the field mapping and payload creation stage.

Additionally, could you please clarify whether Groovy scripts are required for creating the sales order dynamically, and which approach is recommended — hardcoding or dynamic creation?

Thank you very much for your time and guidance.

entry.title: Conversion of the payload to NDJSON
entry.content:
Hello all,

I am wondering if anyone was dealing with a conversion to New Delimited JSON in the iFlow, it is pretty new, and I haven't found any standard tool in the CPI yet /still working on NEO environment/.

Can anyone advise how to convert this? 

{
 "UsersPayload": {
                                  "User": [
                                                 {
                                                    "userId": "XXXXX",
                                                    "manager": "YYYYY"
                                                 },
                                                {
                                                   "userId": "ZZZZZ",
                                                   "manager": "YYYYY"
                                                }
                                                ]
                                }
}
This shall be the JAVA statement that does the magic
const ndjson = jsonData.map(item => JSON.stringify(item)).join('\n');
The trick is to try to convert that to Groovy.
 
Thank you,
Best Regards,
Dagmar

entry.title: Preparing for SAP C_CPE? Here’s How I’m Studying Each Section Without Feeling Overwhelmed
entry.content:
Whenever I start learning something new, I like to have everything in order.
Before I even open the first tutorial, I plan what I’ll study first, what comes next, and how I’ll track it.

Recently, I started preparing for the SAP C_CPE (SAP Certified Associate - Backend Developer - SAP Cloud Application Programming Model) certification. Since this exam covers a mix of BTP architecture, SAP BAS, CAP, Side by side extensions, Cloud Foundry & Kyma Runtime  it can easily feel like too much at once. So I created a simple structure to move step by step without feeling lost.

I began with the learning about BTP, and doing hands on by following SAP Learning Journeys, creating subaccount and adding entitlements and services (It gave me a very clear understanding of BTP architecture) and then Developing appliaction using high productivity tools of SAP BAS, Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) because it’s the foundation of most topics in this certification. I’m spending around two weeks learning about CDS models, service layers and how everything connects in a CAP project. I’m following the official SAP Learning Journey https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-associate-backend-developer-sap-cloud-programming-model and doing small hands-on exercises along the way.

My next focus is Cloud Foundry. I’ll spend about a week learning how to efficiently develop, run, and manage cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime.

After that, I’ll move to Side by side extention on BTP.  This will cover deploying  extension and integrating the app into SAP Build Work Zone.

The next stage is Developing Appliactions in Kyma Environment. I’ll take about two weeks to explore a comprehensive understanding of Kubernetes and to orchestrate the deployment of the applications in the cloud. 

Finally, I’ll study Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK for about two more weeks. These are slightly advanced topics but very useful for understanding to develop and integrate Java, JavaScript, and TypeScript extension applications for SAP solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

So in short, this will be my roadmap-

Recommended Study Sequence

Here’s the order I suggest, from foundational to more advanced :

  1. Exploring SAP Business Technology Platform 5hrs (link : https://learning.sap.com/courses/exploring-sap-business-technology-platform)
    • This gives you a broad overview of the entire platform (services, architecture, what BTP is). Good for building your base understanding.
    • So start here.
  2. Develop Full‑Stack Applications Using Productivity Tools in SAP Business Application Studio 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-full-stack-applications-using-productivity-tools-in-sap-business-application-studio)
    • Once you know the platform, you learn the developer tooling (BAS = Business Application Studio) which is key for CAP and full-stack apps. 
    • So this is your next step.
  3. Develop Applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime 4hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-on-sap-btp-cloud-foundry-runtime)
    • The Cloud Foundry runtime is a major runtime environment in BTP. Understanding how to build and deploy there is critical. 
  4. Build Side‑by‑Side Extensions on SAP BTP 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/build-side-by-side-extensions-on-sap-btp)
    • After tooling and platform basics, you dive into extension scenarios (for example side-by-side extensions of S/4HANA using CAP). This aligns closely with CAP certification topics.
  5. Developing Applications in SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime 8hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-in-sap-btp-kyma-runtime)
    • Kyma Runtime is more advanced (Kubernetes, microservices, event-mesh) and often sits on top of foundational knowledge. 
  6. Develop Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK 11hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-advanced-extensions-with-sap-cloud-sdk)
    • This is relatively specialized/advanced (SAP Cloud SDK, perhaps custom libraries, integrations). Once you’ve mastered the fundamentals above, you go here.

By the end of this plan, I’ll go through a short revision period with mock questions and quick notes from my learning.

This structured approach keeps my study plan clear and prevents me from feeling overwhelmed.
I study for two to four hours a day which feels realistic, and the small milestones make it easier to stay consistent.

If you’re also preparing for C_CPE, it really helps to make your own sequence instead of jumping randomly between topics. The Learning Journeys are excellent resources, but having a personal roadmap makes a big difference.

 

I’d love to hear how others are preparing for this certification too.
What topics are you finding most challenging so far and how are you managing the learning.

entry.title: S/4+EWM - API call for planned Handling Units (HUs)
entry.content:
Hi everyone, I'm currently working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (2023) with SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and I'm trying to automate a delivery from production process using APIs only.

My goal is to create an Inbound Delivery and the corresponding planned Handlings Units. I'm following the documentation provided here: Operations for Handling Unit API

I've been trying for days to create a planned HU via API but it doesn't work. The only thing that worked were stock HUs 😐

Is there any way to create planned Handling Units for a given Product through an API? If yes, could someone please share an examples payload?

I’d really appreciate any tips or suggestions. Thanks a lot!
Bart

entry.title: Plan for migration of interfaces to SAP Cloud Integration(Int. Suite)
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are in to aumotive industry,, This is regarding our ongoing plan to replace all the existing PO/PI instances with the shared SAP Cloud Integration(Int. Suite). As you know, we currently have Team A, Team B, Team C, , each using their own SAP PO/PI system, SAP backends, and individual integration teams. Say for example team A ; team B ;; team C ;;   Also each team has its distinct partner system or common partner system &  common plants between each two teams.  I have the following questions in terms of better architecture, implementation, design, stability, future proof, and operations etc.,

(i) Would it be beneficial for each team to migrate their ICOs to their own Pipeline concept iFlows.

(ii) Should we migrate interfaces system by system (or) plant by plant in a phased manner.

(iii) Standardization and Consistency, Operational Efficiency, Resource Management and Faster Migration (Long-Term), better integration patterns and reducing the complexity etc.

Regards,

Ramu.

entry.title: Salesforce adapter (ROJO) returning a blank exception
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am currently encountering an issue with the upsert operation using ExternalID through the ROJO Salesforce adapter, which is connected via the Request-Reply element. Specifically, the Salesforce upsert operation fails for some records in the clustered payload, resulting in a blank exception, while other records are processed successfully. This integration flow functioned perfectly during QA testing; however, it is now failing in the production environment without any changes made to the integration flow.

I have already attempted to resolve the issue by updating to the latest version of the adapter, but the problem persists.

I would greatly appreciate any guidance or solutions that could assist in resolving this matter.

Thank You

entry.title: CPI Integration Flow: Weather Alert using Open-Meteo API (cities list loop + email notification)
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am working on a scenario in which I want to build an automated iFlow in SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) to send weather alerts. The requirements are as follows:

 

  • Read a list of cities (e.g., Nagpur, Mumbai, Delhi)

  • For each city:

     

    • Fetch latitude & longitude dynamically using the Open-Meteo Geocoding API

    • Then call the Open-Meteo Weather API using those coordinates

    • Read the current temperature value

    • Check for conditions:

      • If temperature > 35 °C → “High Temperature Alert”

      • If temperature < 5 °C → “Low Temperature Alert”

    • Send an email notification with the city name, temperature and the alert message

I have started designing the iFlow with a Timer, looping splitter, HTTP calls, Groovy scripts for extraction and condition logic, and an Email receiver adapter.

What I need help with:

  • Best practice for looping through a list of cities in CPI (should I use an array in a Content Modifier, external CSV, or OData?)

  • How to correctly map and extract the response from the Geocoding API (first result latitude/longitude) → any sample Groovy script or mapping advice would be great

  • How to structure the error handling when an API returns no result or the city name is not found

  • Any suggestions for optimizing the iFlow for performance, especially if the list of cities grows to ~50+

I will also attach a screenshot of my current iFlow configuration (Timer, Splitter, content modifier, HTTP channel, etc.) to show where I am stuck.

If anyone is available and open to help or review the design with me, I would greatly appreciate it. Thank you in advance for your time and advice!

Regards,
Safar

entry.title: What is the simplest way you have seen teams manage integration sprawl in SAP landscapes?
entry.content:
As more cloud apps get connected to SAP, the number of small workflows and automations grows quickly. I am trying to understand how teams maintain visibility and control when dozens of integrations start triggering across systems.

Would love to hear if anyone has a clean way of documenting and monitoring these flows without relying too much on custom scripts or manual maps.
